Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the development of a new method for determining the formation ages of minerals, especially those that cannot currently be dated with existing techniques. The method is based on the ingrowth of a rare isotope of neon - 21Ne - from the decay of uranium and thorium. This technique should be especially useful for dating of iron oxide minerals such as hematite and magnetite, and will likely be applicable to understanding the timing and origin of economically significant ore deposits produced by both sedimentary and hydrothermal processes.

Several important aspects of this dating system will be investigated. First, a set of experiments will be performed to determine the nuclear cross sections for the reaction 18O(α, n) 21Ne, which produces the daughter isotope. These experiments will involve implantation of a known dose of α particles of known energies into various target materials, followed by direct measurement of the 21Ne produced by isotope dilution mass spectrometry. Additional experiments will caharcterize the diffusivity of neon in likely minerals to be dated, which will establish under what temperature conditions neon retention is to be expected. Such data are necessary for accurate interpretation of the measured ages. A final set of experiments will be designed to identify the typical levels of uranium and thorium, as well as non-radiogenic neon, in minerals of interest for dating. These data will provide insight to what types of minerals are promising targets for the dating method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dating of minerals – geochronology – is essential to understanding geologic processes. While many minerals can be dated by existing methods involving the accumulation of radioactive-decay products, other minerals, including some that are both common and geologically and economically important, cannot. This grant supported the development and application of a new methodology for mineral dating, based on the accumulation of neon. This noble gas is in very low abundance in nature, but is produced when decay of common radioactive elements in minerals ejects a small nuclear particle that strikes a nearby atom of oxygen. In a small number of such collisions the oxygen is converted to neon. By measuring the amount of neon in a mineral, it is in principle possible to determine the mineral's age. To establish this technique as a viable dating method, this grant established the probability that the conversion of oxygen to neon will occur. This was accomplished through an experiment that mimics the natural nuclear reaction but under carefully controlled laboratory conditions. It also established under what temperature conditions neon will stay in the mineral. Being a small unreactive atom, neon has a propensity to diffuse away and be lost. At high temperatures this propensity increases, and can be sufficiently great that the "neon age" is compromised – not all neon produced is retained and the age would be anomalously young. Work under this grant established that in the common mineral hematite (Fe2O3), neon does not diffuse over geologic time at temperatures less than about 300oC. This is a critical result because this mineral is commonly formed at temperatures below this value, hence the accumulation of neon can be used to establish the time at which the mineral grew. Hematite was chosen for this work because it is among the important minerals that cannot be dated by known alternatives.

To demonstrate the applicability of this new method, hematite from an iron ore deposit in Michigan was analyzed. While the Fe ore deposits of the upper Midwest were of great ecomonic significance and drove industrialization of the region in the early 20th century, when and how this Fe ore was produced is poorly known. Dates obtained from the neon method suggest several episodes of mineralization, and are not easily reconciled with any previous ideas for how the ore formed. This specific application is likely to be of interest to the global iron mining industry, because most mined Fe ores are genetically similar to those in Michigan. It is also likely that this will be the first of at least a handful of minerals that can be dated using this new technqiue.

This research was undertaken primarily by two young investigators, a post-doctoral researcher and a PhD student. Their growth into contributing independent scientists was facilitated by this grant.
